questions.content: A period 3 element, M, forms an oxide of the type M2O. Which represents the first four successive ionization energies of M?

16N.2.hl.TZ0.4d.excerpt: (i) Explain the convergence of lines in a hydrogen emission spectrum.(ii) State what can be determined from the frequency of the convergence limit.
specification: Magnesium is a group 2 metal which exists as a number of isotopes and forms many compounds.

questions.content: Magnesium ions produce no emission or absorption lines in the visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum. Suggest why most magnesium compounds tested in a school laboratory show traces of yellow in the flame.
questions.label: c

questions.content:
(i) Explain the convergence of lines in a hydrogen emission spectrum.


(ii) State what can be determined from the frequency of the convergence limit.
questions.label: d
markscheme:
i
energy levels are closer together at high energy / high frequency / short wavelength

questions.content:
Magnesium chloride can be electrolysed.


(i) Deduce the half-equations for the reactions at each electrode when molten magnesium chloride is electrolysed, showing the state symbols of the products. The melting points of magnesium and magnesium chloride are 922K and 987K respectively.



(ii) Identify the type of reaction occurring at the cathode (negative electrode).


(iii) State the products when a very dilute aqueous solution of magnesium chloride is electrolysed.
questions.label: i
markscheme: Penalize missing/incorrect state symbols atCl2 and Mg once only.
Award [1 max] if equations are at wrong electrodes.
Award [1 max] if correct products given at wrong electrodes.

questions.content: Standard electrode potentials are measured relative to the standard hydrogen electrode. Describe a standard hydrogen electrode.
questions.label: j
markscheme:
Accept 1 atm H2(g).
Accept 1 bar H2(g)
Accept a labelled diagram.
Ignore temperature if it is specified.

questions.content:
A magnesium half-cell, Mg(s)/Mg2+(aq), can be connected to a copper half-cell, Cu(s)/Cu2+(aq).


(i) Formulate an equation for the spontaneous reaction that occurs when the circuit is completed.


(ii) Determine the standard cell potential, in V, for the cell. Refer to section 24 of the data booklet.


(iii) Predict, giving a reason, the change in cell potential when the concentration of copper ions increases.
questions.label: k
markscheme:
reaction «in Q4(k)(i)» moves to the right
OR
potential of the copper half-cell increases/becomes more positive
Accept correct answers based on the Nernst equation

17M.2.hl.TZ1.2d.iii.excerpt: Sketch a graph of the first six successive ionization energies of vanadium on the axes provided.
specification: Titanium and vanadium are consecutive elements in the first transition metal series.
\({\text{TiC}}{{\text{l}}_{\text{4}}}\) reacts with water and the resulting titanium(IV) oxide can be used as a smoke screen.

questions.content: Describe the bonding in metals.
questions.label: a

questions.content:
Titanium exists as several isotopes. The mass spectrum of a sample of titanium gave the following data:



Calculate the relative atomic mass of titanium to two decimal places.
questions.label: b
markscheme: Answer must have two decimal placeswith a value from 47.90 to 48.00.

questions.content: State the number of protons, neutrons and electrons in the \(_{{\text{22}}}^{{\text{48}}}{\text{Ti}}\) atom.
questions.label: c

questions.content: State the full electron configuration of the \(_{{\text{22}}}^{{\text{48}}}{\text{T}}{{\text{i}}^{2 + }}\) ion.
questions.label: d.i

questions.content: Suggest why the melting point of vanadium is higher than that of titanium.
questions.label: d.ii
markscheme: vanadium has smaller ionic radius «leading to stronger metallic bonding»
Accept vanadium has «one» morevalence electron«s» «leading to stronger metallic bonding».

questions.content: Sketch a graph of the first six successive ionization energies of vanadium on the axes provided.
questions.label: d.iii
markscheme: regular increase for first five AND sharp increase to the 6th
Accept log plot on given axes (withoutamendment of y-axis).
Award mark if gradient of 5 to 6 isgreater than “best fit line” of 1 to 5.

questions.content: Explain why an aluminium-titanium alloy is harder than pure aluminium.
questions.label: d.iv
markscheme: titanium atoms/ions distort the regular arrangement of atoms/ions
titanium atoms/ions are a different size to aluminium «atoms/ions»

questions.content: Describe, in terms of the electrons involved, how the bond between a ligand and a central metal ion is formed.
questions.label: e
markscheme: pair of electrons provided by the ligand

questions.content: Outline why transition metals form coloured compounds.
questions.label: f
markscheme:
light is absorbed as electrons transit to a higher energy level «in d–d transitions»
OR
light is absorbed as electrons are promoted
energy gap corresponds to light in the visible region of the spectrum

questions.content: State the type of bonding in potassium chloride which melts at 1043 K.
questions.label: g.i

questions.content: A chloride of titanium, \({\text{TiC}}{{\text{l}}_{\text{4}}}\), melts at 248 K. Suggest why the melting point is so much lower than that of KCl.
questions.label: g.ii
markscheme: Accept specific examples of weakbonds such as London/dispersion andvan der Waals.

questions.content: Formulate an equation for this reaction.
questions.label: h.i
markscheme: Award M2 if products are HCl and acompound of Ti and O.

questions.content: Suggest one disadvantage of using this smoke in an enclosed space.
questions.label: h.ii

17M.1.hl.TZ1.5.excerpt: Which statement explains one of the decreases in first ionization energy (I.E.) across period 3? A.     The nuclear charge of element Al is greater than element Mg.B.     The electron-electron repulsion is greater, for the electron with the opposite spin, in element S than in element P.C.     A new sub-level is being filled at element S.D.     The p orbital being filled in element Al is at a lower energy than the s orbital in element Mg.

questions.content:
Which statement explains one of the decreases in first ionization energy (I.E.) across period 3?


 


A.     The nuclear charge of element Al is greater than element Mg.


B.     The electron-electron repulsion is greater, for the electron with the opposite spin, in element S than in element P.


C.     A new sub-level is being filled at element S.


D.     The p orbital being filled in element Al is at a lower energy than the s orbital in element Mg.

17M.2.hl.TZ2.4c.excerpt: The first six ionization energies, in kJ mol–1, of an element are given below.Explain the large increase in ionization energy from IE3 to IE4.
specification: Bonds can be formed in many ways.
Bonds can be formed in many ways.

The equilibrium for a mixture of NO2 and N2O4 gases is represented as:
2NO2(g) \( \rightleftharpoons \) N2O4(g)
At 100°C, the equilibrium constant, Kc, is 0.21.

questions.content: Discuss the bonding in the resonance structures of ozone.
questions.label: b.i
markscheme: lone pair on p orbital «of O atom» overlaps/delocalizes with pi electrons «fromdouble bond»

both O–O bonds have equal bond length
OR
both O–O bonds have same/1.5 bond order
OR
both O–O are intermediate between O–O AND O=O
both O–O bonds have equal bond energy

questions.content: Deduce one resonance structure of ozone and the corresponding formal charges on each oxygen atom.
questions.label: b.ii
markscheme: Accept any combination of lines, dots orcrosses to represent electrons.
Do not accept structure that represents1.5 bonds.
Do not penalize missing lone pairs ifalready penalized in 3(b).
Any one of the structures with correctformal charges for [2 max].

questions.content:
The first six ionization energies, in kJ mol–1, of an element are given below.



Explain the large increase in ionization energy from IE3 to IE4.
questions.label: c
markscheme:
Any two of:
IE4: electron in lower/inner shell/energy level
OR
IE4: more stable/full electron shell

IE4: electron closer to nucleus
OR
IE4: electron more tightly held by nucleus
IE4: less shielding by complete inner shells

questions.content:
At a given time, the concentration of NO2(g) and N2O4(g) were 0.52 and \(0.10{\text{ mol}}\,{\text{d}}{{\text{m}}^{ - 3}}\) respectively.


Deduce, showing your reasoning, if the forward or the reverse reaction is favoured at this time.
questions.label: d.i
markscheme:
«Qc = \(\frac{{0.10}}{{{{0.52}^2}}}\) =» 0.37
reaction proceeds to the left/NO2(g) «until Q = Kc»
OR
reverse reaction «favoured»
Do not award M2 without a calculationfor M1 but remember to apply ECF.

questions.content: Comment on the value of ΔG when the reaction quotient equals the equilibrium constant, Q = K.
questions.label: d.ii
markscheme:
ΔG =0
reaction at equilibrium
OR
rate of forward and reverse reaction is the same
OR
constant macroscopic properties

20N.2.hl.TZ0.6a.excerpt: The electron configuration of copper makes it a useful metal.Determine the frequency of a photon that will cause the first ionization of copper. Use sections 1, 2 and 8 of the data booklet.

questions.content:
The electron configuration of copper makes it a useful metal.


Determine the frequency of a photon that will cause the first ionization of copper. Use sections 1, 2 and 8 of the data booklet.
questions.label: a

questions.content:
The electron configuration of copper makes it a useful metal.


Explain why a copper(II) solution is blue, using section 17 of the data booklet.
questions.label: b
markscheme: orange light is absorbed «and the complementary colour is observed» ✔

Any TWO from:
partially filled d-orbitals ✔
«ligands/water cause» d-orbitals «to» split ✔
light is absorbed as electrons move to a higher energy orbital «in d–d transitions»
OR
light is absorbed as electrons are promoted ✔
energy gap corresponds to «orange» light in the visible region of the spectrum ✔

questions.content:
The electron configuration of copper makes it a useful metal.


Copper plating can be used to improve the conductivity of an object.


State, giving your reason, at which electrode the object being electroplated should be placed.
questions.label: c

Which factor explains why element X has a higher first ionisation energy than element Y?


A.  Element Y loses an electron from a different sub-level.


B.  Element Y has a smaller atomic radius.


C.  Element X has a full octet.


D.  Element Y has a greater nuclear charge.

21M.2.hl.TZ1.1c.excerpt: Sketch the first eight successive ionisation energies of sulfur.
specification: Iron may be extracted from iron (II) sulfide, FeS.
Iron (II) sulfide, FeS, is ionically bonded.
The first step in the extraction of iron from iron (II) sulfide is to roast it in air to form iron (III) oxide and sulfur dioxide.

questions.content: Outline why metals, like iron, can conduct electricity.
questions.label: a

questions.content: Justify why sulfur is classified as a non-metal by giving two of its chemical properties.
questions.label: b
markscheme: behaves as an oxidizing agent «rather than a reducing agent» ✔
Award [1 max] for 2 correct non-chemical properties such as non-conductor, high ionisation energy, high electronegativity, low electron affinity if no marks for chemical properties are awarded.

questions.content: Sketch the first eight successive ionisation energies of sulfur.
questions.label: c
markscheme: two regions of small increases AND a large increase between them✔

questions.content: Describe the bonding in this type of solid.
questions.label: d(i)
markscheme: between oppositely charged ions/between Fe2+ and S2−✔

questions.content: State a technique that could be used to determine the crystal structure of the solid compound.
questions.label: d(ii)

questions.content: State the full electron configuration of the sulfide ion.
questions.label: d(iii)

questions.content: Outline, in terms of their electronic structures, why the ionic radius of the sulfide ion is greater than that of the oxide ion.
questions.label: d(iv)
markscheme: «valence» electrons further from nucleus/extra electron shell/ electrons in third/3s/3p level «not second/2s/2p»✔

questions.content: Suggest why chemists find it convenient to classify bonding into ionic, covalent and metallic.
questions.label: d(v)
markscheme:
allows them to explain the properties of different compounds/substances
OR
enables them to generalise about substances
OR
enables them to make predictions ✔

questions.content: Write the equation for this reaction.
questions.label: e(i)

questions.content: Deduce the change in the oxidation state of sulfur.
questions.label: e(ii)

questions.content: Suggest why this process might raise environmental concerns.
questions.label: e(iii)
markscheme:
Accept sulfur dioxide/SO2/dust causes respiratory problems
Do not accept just “causes respiratory problems” or “causes acid rain”.

questions.content: Explain why the addition of small amounts of carbon to iron makes the metal harder.
questions.label: f
markscheme:
disrupts the regular arrangement «of iron atoms/ions»
OR
carbon different size «to iron atoms/ions» ✔

21M.2.hl.TZ2.2a(ii).excerpt: Explain why the first ionization energy of sulfur is lower than that of phosphorus.
specification: The properties of elements can be predicted from their position in the periodic table.

questions.content: Explain why Si has a smaller atomic radius than Al.
questions.label: a(i)
markscheme: nuclear charge/number of protons/Z/Zeff increases «causing a stronger pull on the outer electrons» ✓

questions.content: Explain why the first ionization energy of sulfur is lower than that of phosphorus.
questions.label: a(ii)
markscheme:
P has «three» unpaired electrons in 3p sub-level AND S has one full 3p orbital «and two 3p orbitals with unpaired electrons»
OR
P: [Ne]3s23px13py13pz1 AND S: [Ne]3s23px23py13pz1 ✓
Accept orbital diagrams for 3p sub-level for M1. Ignore other orbitals or sub-levels.
repulsion between paired electrons in sulfur «and therefore easier to remove» ✓
Accept “removing electron from S gives more stable half-filled sub-level" for M2.

questions.content: State the condensed electron configurations for Cr and Cr3+.
questions.label: b(i)
markscheme: Award [1 max] for two correct full electron configurations “1s22s22p63s23p64s13d5 AND 1s22s22p63s23p63d3”.

questions.content: Describe metallic bonding and how it contributes to electrical conductivity.
questions.label: b(ii)
markscheme: between «a lattice of» cations/positive «metal» ions AND «a sea of» delocalized electrons ✓

mobile electrons responsible for conductivity
OR
electrons move when a voltage/potential difference/electric field is applied ✓
Accept “electrons move when connected to a cell/battery/power supply” OR “electrons move when connected in a circuit” for M3.

questions.content: Deduce, giving a reason, which complex ion [Cr(CN)6]3− or [Cr(OH)6]3− absorbs higher energy light. Use section 15 of the data booklet.
questions.label: b(iii)
markscheme:
[Cr(CN)6]3− AND CN−/ligand causes larger splitting «in d-orbitals compared to OH−»
OR
[Cr(CN)6]3− AND CN−/ligand associated with a higher Δ/«crystal field» splitting energy/energy difference «in the spectrochemical series compared to OH− » ✓

questions.content: [Cr(OH)6]3− forms a green solution. Estimate a wavelength of light absorbed by this complex, using section 17 of the data booklet.
questions.label: b(iv)
markscheme: any value or range between 647 and 700 nm ✓

questions.content: Deduce the Lewis (electron dot) structure and molecular geometry of sulfur tetrafluoride, SF4, and sulfur dichloride, SCl2.
questions.label: c
markscheme:
SF4/SCl2 structure does not have to be 3-D for mark.

Penalize missing lone pairs of electrons on halogens once only.

Accept any combination of dots, lines or crosses for bonds/lone pairs.

Accept “non-linear” for SCl2 molecular geometry.

Award [1] for two correct electron domain geometries, e.g. trigonal bipyramidal for SF4 and tetrahedral for SCl2.

questions.content: Suggest, giving reasons, the relative volatilities of SCl2 and H2O.
questions.label: d
markscheme: H2O forms hydrogen bonding «while SCl2 does not» ✓
SCl2 «much» stronger London/dispersion/«instantaneous» induced dipole-induced dipole forces ✓

Alternative 1:
H2O less volatile AND hydrogen bonding stronger «than dipole–dipole and dispersion forces» ✓

Alternative 2:
SCl2 less volatile AND effect of dispersion forces «could be» greater than hydrogen bonding ✓
Accept “SCl2 has «much» larger molar mass/electron density” for M2.

22M.2.hl.TZ1.1e(iv).excerpt: Suggest, giving a reason, whether magnesium or nitrogen would have the greater sixth ionization...
specification: When heated in air, magnesium ribbon reacts with oxygen to form magnesium oxide.

The reaction in (a)(i) was carried out in a crucible with a lid and the following data was recorded:
Mass of crucible and lid = 47.372 ±0.001 g
Mass of crucible, lid and magnesium ribbon before heating = 53.726 ±0.001 g
Mass of crucible, lid and product after heating = 56.941 ±0.001 g

When magnesium is burnt in air, some of it reacts with nitrogen to form magnesium nitride according to the equation:
3 Mg (s) + N2 (g) → Mg3N2 (s)
The presence of magnesium nitride can be demonstrated by adding water to the product. It is hydrolysed to form magnesium hydroxide and ammonia.
Most nitride ions are 14N3–.

questions.content: Write a balanced equation for the reaction that occurs.
questions.label: a(i)
markscheme: Do not accept equilibrium arrows. Ignore state symbols

questions.content: Identify a metal, in the same period as magnesium, that does not form a basic oxide.
questions.label: a(ii)

questions.content: Calculate the amount of magnesium, in mol, that was used.
questions.label: b(i)

questions.content: Determine the percentage uncertainty of the mass of product after heating.
questions.label: b(ii)

questions.content: Assume the reaction in (a)(i) is the only one occurring and it goes to completion, but some product has been lost from the crucible. Deduce the percentage yield of magnesium oxide in the crucible.
questions.label: b(iii)
markscheme: Accept alternative methods to arrive at the correct answer.

questions.content: Evaluate whether this, rather than the loss of product, could explain the yield found in (b)(iii).
questions.label: c(i)
markscheme:
yes
AND
«each Mg combines with23N, so» mass increase would be 14x23which is less than expected increase of 16x
OR
3 mol Mg would form 101g of Mg3N2 but would form 3 x MgO = 121 g of MgO
OR
0.2614 mol forms 10.536 g of MgO, but would form 8.796 g of Mg3N2 ✔
Accept Yes AND “the mass of N/N2 that combines with each g/mole of Mg is lower than that of O/O2”
Accept YES AND “molar mass of nitrogen less than of oxygen”.

questions.content: Suggest an explanation, other than product being lost from the crucible or reacting with nitrogen, that could explain the yield found in (b)(iii).
questions.label: c(ii)
markscheme:
incomplete reaction
OR
Mg was partially oxidised already
OR
impurity present that evaporated/did not react ✔
Accept answers relating to a higher atomic mass impurity consuming less O/O2.
Do not accept "human error", "wrongly calibrated balance" or other non-chemical reasons.
If answer to (b)(iii) is >100%, accept appropriate reasons, such as product absorbed moisture before being weighed.

questions.content: Calculate coefficients that balance the equation for the following reaction.
questions.label: d(i)

questions.content: Ammonia is added to water that contains a few drops of an indicator. Identify an indicator that would change colour. Use sections 21 and 22 of the data booklet.
questions.label: d(ii)

questions.content: Determine the oxidation state of nitrogen in Mg3N2 and in NH3.
questions.label: d(iii)

questions.content: Deduce, giving reasons, whether the reaction of magnesium nitride with water is an acid–base reaction, a redox reaction, neither or both.
questions.label: d(iv)
markscheme:
Acid–base:
yes AND N3- accepts H+/donates electron pair«s»
OR
yes AND H2O loses H+ «to form OH-»/accepts electron pair«s» ✔
Accept reference to the oxidation state of specific elements not changing.
Award [1 max] for Acid–base: yes AND Redox: no without correct reasons, if no other mark has been awarded

questions.content: State the number of subatomic particles in this ion.
questions.label: e(i)

questions.content: Some nitride ions are 15N3–. State the term that describes the relationship between 14N3– and 15N3–.
questions.label: e(ii)

questions.content: The nitride ion and the magnesium ion are isoelectronic (they have the same electron configuration). Determine, giving a reason, which has the greater ionic radius.
questions.label: e(iii)

questions.content: Suggest, giving a reason, whether magnesium or nitrogen would have the greater sixth ionization energy.
questions.label: e(iv)
markscheme:
nitrogen AND electron lost from first «energy» level/s sub-level/s-orbital AND magnesium from p sub-level/p-orbital/second «energy» level
OR
nitrogen AND electron lost from lower level «than magnesium» ✔
Accept “nitrogen AND electron lost closer to the nucleus «than magnesium»”.

questions.content: Suggest two reasons why atoms are no longer regarded as the indivisible units of matter.
questions.label: f
markscheme:
subatomic particles «discovered»
OR
particles smaller/with masses less than atoms «discovered»
OR
«existence of» isotopes «same number of protons, different number of neutrons» ✔

charged particles obtained from «neutral» atoms
OR
atoms can gain or lose electrons «and become charged» ✔
Accept atoms can undergo fusion «to produce heavier atoms»
Award [2] for “atom shown to have a nucleus with electrons around it” as both M1 and M3.

questions.content: State the types of bonding in magnesium, oxygen and magnesium oxide, and how the valence electrons produce these types of bonding.
questions.label: g

22M.2.hl.TZ2.5a(ii).excerpt: Explain why there is a large increase from the 8th to the 9th ionization energy of iron.
specification: Iron(II) disulfide, FeS2, has been mistaken for gold.

questions.content: State the full electronic configuration of Fe2+.
questions.label: a(i)

questions.content: Explain why there is a large increase from the 8th to the 9th ionization energy of iron.
questions.label: a(ii)
markscheme:
IE9: electron in lower energy level
OR
IE9: more stable/full electron level ✔

IE9: electron closer to nucleus
OR
IE9: electron more tightly held by nucleus ✔

questions.content: Calculate the oxidation state of sulfur in iron(II) disulfide, FeS2.
questions.label: b

questions.content: Describe the bonding in iron, Fe (s).
questions.label: c
markscheme: electrostatic attraction/hold between «lattice of» positive ions/cations AND delocalized «valence» electrons ✔

19M.2.hl.TZ1.3a.excerpt: Plot the relative values of the first four ionization energies of sodium.
specification: This question is about sodium and its compounds.
The Born-Haber cycle for sodium oxide is shown (not to scale).

Sodium peroxide is used in diving apparatus to produce oxygen from carbon dioxide.
2Na2O2 (s) + 2CO2 (g) → 2Na2CO3 (s) + O2 (g)

questions.content: Plot the relative values of the first four ionization energies of sodium.
questions.label: a
markscheme:
Notes: Accept curve showing general trend.
Award mark only if the energy difference between the first two points is larger than that between points 2/3 and 3/4.

questions.content: Outline why the alkali metals (group 1) have similar chemical properties.
questions.label: b
markscheme: same number of electrons in outer shell
all are s1[✔]

questions.content: Describe the structure and bonding in solid sodium oxide.
questions.label: c
markscheme:
electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions
OR
electrostatic attraction between Na+ and O2− ions [✔]

questions.content:
Calculate values for the following changes using section 8 of the data booklet.



ΔHatomisation (Na) = 107 kJ mol−1
ΔHatomisation (O) = 249 kJ mol−1


1 2 O2(g) → O2- (g):


Na (s) → Na+ (g):
questions.label: d(i)
markscheme: 1 2 O2(g) → O2- (g)
«ΔHatomisation (O) + 1st EA + 2nd EA = 249 k Jmol−1 − 141 kJmol−1 + 753 kJmol−1 =» «+»861 «kJmol−1» [✔]
Na (s) → Na+ (g)
«ΔHatomisation (Na) + 1st IE = 107 kJmol−1 + 496 kJmol−1 =» «+»603 «kJmol−1» [✔]

questions.content:
The standard enthalpy of formation of sodium oxide is −414 kJ mol−1. Determine the lattice enthalpy of sodium oxide, in kJ mol−1, using section 8 of the data booklet and your answers to (d)(i).



(If you did not get answers to (d)(i), use +850 kJ mol−1 and +600 kJ mol−1 respectively, but these are not the correct answers.)
questions.label: d(ii)
markscheme: «= +» 2481 «kJ mol−1» [✔]
Note:Award [2] for correct final answer.

If given values are used:
M1: lattice enthalpy = 850 «kJ mol−1» +
2× 600 «kJ mol−1» −(−414 «kJ mol−1»)
M2: «= +» 2464 «kJ mol−1»

questions.content: Justify why K2O has a lower lattice enthalpy (absolute value) than Na2O.
questions.label: d(iii)
markscheme: K+ ion is larger than Na+
smaller attractive force because of greater distance between ion «centres» [✔]

questions.content:
Write equations for the separate reactions of solid sodium oxide and solid phosphorus(V) oxide with excess water and differentiate between the solutions formed.


Sodium oxide, Na2O:


Phosphorus(V) oxide, P4O10:


Differentiation:
questions.label: e
markscheme:
Phosphorus(V) oxide:
P4O10 (s) + 6H2O(l) → 4H3PO4 (aq) [✔]

Differentiation:
NaOH/product of Na2O is alkaline/basic/pH > 7 AND H3PO4/product of P4O10 is acidic/pH < 7 [✔]

questions.content:
Sodium peroxide, Na2O2, is formed by the reaction of sodium oxide with oxygen.


2Na2O (s) + O2 (g) → 2Na2O2 (s)


Calculate the percentage yield of sodium peroxide if 5.00g of sodium oxide produces 5.50g of sodium peroxide.
questions.label: f
markscheme: n(Na2O2) theoretical yield «= 5.00 g 61.98 g mo l − 1 » = 0.0807/8.07 × 10−2 «mol»
mass of Na2O2 theoretical yield «= 5.00 g 61.98 g mo l − 1 × 77.98 gmol−1» = 6.291 «g» [✔]
% yield «= 5.50 g 6.291 g × 100» OR « 0.0705 0.0807 ×100» = 87.4 «%» [✔]

questions.content: Determine the enthalpy change, ΔH, in kJ, for this reaction using data from the table and section 12 of the data booklet.
questions.label: g(i)
markscheme: ∑ΔHfreactants = 2 × (−510.9) + 2 × (−393.5) / −1808.8 «kJ» [✔]
ΔH= «∑ΔHf products − ∑ΔHf reactants = −2261.4 −(−1808.8) =» −452.6 «kJ» [✔]

questions.content: Outline why bond enthalpy values are not valid in calculations such as that in (g)(i).
questions.label: g(ii)

questions.content: An allotrope of molecular oxygen is ozone. Compare, giving a reason, the bond enthalpies of the O to O bonds in O2 and O3.
questions.label: h
markscheme: bond in O3 has lower enthalpy AND bond order is 1.5 «not 2» [✔]

questions.content: Outline why a real gas differs from ideal behaviour at low temperature and high pressure.
questions.label: i
markscheme: finite volume of particles «requires adjustment to volume of gas» [✔]
short-range attractive forces «overcomes low kinetic energy» [✔]

questions.content: The reaction of sodium peroxide with excess water produces hydrogen peroxide and one other sodium compound. Suggest the formula of this compound.
questions.label: j

questions.content: State the oxidation number of carbon in sodium carbonate, Na2CO3.
questions.label: k

19M.2.hl.TZ2.3c.excerpt: Explain why the first ionization energy of nitrogen is greater than both carbon and oxygen.Nitrogen and carbon
specification: Dinitrogen monoxide, N2O, causes depletion of ozone in the stratosphere.
Different sources of N2O have different ratios of 14N : 15N.
The Lewis (electron dot) structure of the dinitrogen monoxide molecule can be represented as:

questions.content: Outline why ozone in the stratosphere is important.
questions.label: a(i)
markscheme: absorbs UV/ultraviolet light «of longer wavelength than absorbed by O2» [✔]

questions.content:
Dinitrogen monoxide in the stratosphere is converted to nitrogen monoxide, NO (g).


Write two equations to show how NO (g) catalyses the decomposition of ozone.
questions.label: a(ii)
markscheme:
NO (g) + O3 (g) → NO2 (g) + O2 (g) [✔]
NO2 (g) + O3 (g) → NO (g) + 2O2 (g) [✔]
Award [1 max] for NO2 (g) + O (g) → NO (g) + O2 (g).

questions.content: State one analytical technique that could be used to determine the ratio of 14N : 15N.
questions.label: b(i)
markscheme: mass spectrometry/MS [✔]

questions.content:
A sample of gas was enriched to contain 2 % by mass of 15N with the remainder being 14N.


Calculate the relative molecular mass of the resulting N2O.
questions.label: b(ii)
markscheme: « ( 98 × 14 ) + ( 2 × 15 ) 100 =» 14.02 [✔]

questions.content: Predict, giving two reasons, how the first ionization energy of 15N compares with that of 14N.
questions.label: b(iii)
markscheme: same AND have same nuclear charge /number of protons/Zeff [✔]

same AND neutrons do not affect attraction/ionization energy/Zeff
OR
same AND neutrons have no charge [✔]
same AND same attraction for «outer» electrons [✔]
same AND have same electronic configuration/shielding [✔]
Note:Accept “almost the same”.
“Same” only needs to be stated once.

questions.content:
Explain why the first ionization energy of nitrogen is greater than both carbon and oxygen.


Nitrogen and carbon:


Nitrogen and oxygen:
questions.label: c
markscheme: N has greater nuclear charge/«one» more proton «and electrons both lost from singly filled p-orbitals» [✔]

O has a doubly filled «p-»orbital
OR
N has only singly occupied «p-»orbitals [✔]
Note:Accept “greater e– - e- repulsion in O” or “lower e– - e- repulsion in N”.
Accept box annotation of electrons for M2.

questions.content: State what the presence of alternative Lewis structures shows about the nature of the bonding in the molecule.
questions.label: d(i)

questions.content: State, giving a reason, the shape of the dinitrogen monoxide molecule.
questions.label: d(ii)
markscheme: Note:Accept “two bonds AND no lone pairs” for reason.

questions.content: Deduce the hybridization of the central nitrogen atom in the molecule.
questions.label: d(iii)

19N.2.hl.TZ0.1e(ii).excerpt: Determine, showing your working, the wavelength, in m, of ultraviolet light absorbed by a single molecule in one of these steps. Use sections 1, 2 and 11 of the data booklet.
specification:
The equations show steps in the formation and decomposition of ozone in the stratosphere, some of which absorb ultraviolet light.
Step 1    O2 → 2O•
Step 2    O• + O2 → O3
Step 3    O3 → O• + O2
Step 4    O• + O3 → 2O2

questions.content: Draw the Lewis structures of oxygen, O2, and ozone, O3.
questions.label: a
markscheme: NOTES: Coordinate bond may be represented by an arrow.

questions.content:
Outline why both bonds in the ozone molecule are the same length and predict the bond length in the ozone molecule. Refer to section 10 of the data booklet.


Reason: 


Length:
questions.label: b
markscheme:
resonance «structures»
OR
delocalization of «the double/pi bond» electrons ✔
121 «pm» < length < 148 «pm» ✔
NOTE:Accept any length between these two values.

questions.content: Predict the bond angle in the ozone molecule.
questions.label: c

questions.content: Discuss how the different bond strengths between the oxygen atoms in O2 and O3 in the ozone layer affect radiation reaching the Earth’s surface.
questions.label: d
markscheme: «bond» in O2 stronger than in O3 ✔

ozone absorbs lower frequency/energy «radiation than oxygen»
OR
ozone absorbs longer wavelength «radiation than oxygen» ✔
NOTE:Accept ozone «layer» absorbs a range of frequencies.

questions.content: Identify the steps which absorb ultraviolet light.
questions.label: e(i)

questions.content: Determine, showing your working, the wavelength, in m, of ultraviolet light absorbed by a single molecule in one of these steps. Use sections 1, 2 and 11 of the data booklet.
questions.label: e(ii)
markscheme: λ=«6.63×10−34 J s×3.00×108 m s−18.27×10−19 J=» 2.40×10−7 «m»✔
similar calculation using 200 < bond enthalpy < 400 for ozone, such as
E=«300 000 J mol−16.02×1023 mol−1=» 4.98×10−19«J»✔
λ=«6.63×10−34 J s×3.00×108 m s−14.98×10−19 J=» 3.99×10−7 «m»✔
NOTE:Award [2] for correct final answer.

Show how nitrogen monoxide catalyses the decomposition of ozone, including equations in your answer.
